com.bigdata.rdf.sparql.ast.optimizers

Class TestASTConstructOptimizer

  • java.lang.Object
    • junit.framework.Assert
      • junit.framework.TestCase
        • junit.framework.TestCase2
          • com.bigdata.bop.engine.AbstractQueryEngineTestCase
            • com.bigdata.rdf.sparql.ast.AbstractASTEvaluationTestCase
              • com.bigdata.rdf.sparql.ast.optimizers.TestASTConstructOptimizer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    junit.framework.Test

    public class TestASTConstructOptimizer
extends AbstractASTEvaluationTestCase
    Test suite for the ASTConstructOptimizer. This is applied for both DESCRIBE and CONSTRUCT queries. It generates the ProjectionNode, populating it with all of the variables in the ConstructNode.
    Version:
    $Id$
    Author:
    Bryan Thompson

    • Method Detail

      • test_construct_rewrite

        public void test_construct_rewrite()
        Unit test for the AST rewrite of a CONSTRUCT query based on the hand-coded rewrite of a simple DESCRIBE query involving an IRI and a variable bound by a WHERE clause. The IRI in this case was chosen such that it would not be selected by the WHERE clause. 
         describe  ?x 
 where {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 }
        This test verifies that the correct CONSTRUCT clause is generated and that a WHERE clause is added which will capture the necessary bindings to support that CONSTUCT while preserving the original WHERE clause.

      • test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_none

        public void test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_none()
        Unit test for a CONSTRUCT query with NO solution modifiers. This is the base case for the next several unit tests. 
         CONSTRUCT {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 } 
 WHERE {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 }
        See Also:
        DESCRIBE with OFFSET/LIMIT must use sub-SELECT

      • test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_offsetLimit

        public void test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_offsetLimit()
        Unit test verifies that a CONSTRUCT query (DESCRIBE is rewritten as CONSTRUCT) with an OFFSET/LIMIT pushes the original WHERE clause and the OFFSET/LIMIT into a sub-SELECT. This is necessary in order for the slice to be applied to the WHERE clause rather than the triples in the CONSTRUCTed graph. For example: 
         CONSTRUCT {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 } 
 WHERE {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 }
 OFFSET 1
 LIMIT 1
        is turned into the following: 
         CONSTRUCT {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 } 
 WHERE {
    SELECT ?x WHERE {
      ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
    }
    OFFSET 1
    LIMIT 1
 }
        Note: If an ORDER BY clause is also present, then it must also be pushed into the sub-SELECT. However, if only an ORDER BY clause is present (without an OFFSET/LIMIT), then the ORDER BY clause should simply be dropped.
        See Also:
        DESCRIBE with OFFSET/LIMIT must use sub-SELECT

      • test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_offsetLimit_orderBy

        public void test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_offsetLimit_orderBy()
        Unit test verifies that a CONSTRUCT query (DESCRIBE is rewritten as CONSTRUCT) with an OFFSET/LIMIT and an ORDER BY pushes the original WHERE clause, the OFFSET/LIMIT, and the ORDER BY into a sub-SELECT. This is necessary in order for the SLICE and the ORDER BY to be applied to the WHERE clause rather than the triples in the CONSTRUCTed graph. For example: 
         CONSTRUCT {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 } 
 WHERE {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 }
 ORDER BY ?x
 OFFSET 1
 LIMIT 1
        is turned into the following: 
         CONSTRUCT {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 } 
 WHERE {
    SELECT ?x WHERE {
      ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
    }
    ORDER BY ?x
    OFFSET 1
    LIMIT 1
 }
        Note: If an ORDER BY clause is also present, then it must also be pushed into the sub-SELECT. However, if only an ORDER BY clause is present (without an OFFSET/LIMIT), then the ORDER BY clause should simply be dropped.
        See Also:
        DESCRIBE with OFFSET/LIMIT must use sub-SELECT

      • test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_orderBy

        public void test_construct_withSolutionModifiers_orderBy()
        Variant on the test above verifies that a CONSTRUCT query (DESCRIBE is rewritten as CONSTRUCT) with an ORDER_BY clause drops the ORDER_BY clause when OFFSET/LIMIT are not present. 
         CONSTRUCT {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 } 
 WHERE {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 }
 ORDER BY ?x
        is turned into the following: 
         CONSTRUCT {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 } 
 WHERE {
   ?x rdf:type foaf:Person
 }
        See Also:
        DESCRIBE with OFFSET/LIMIT must use sub-SELECT
